data.title: Support for compressed SoundEffects
data.body: SoundEffects are processed with the Content Pipeline Tool to an uncompressed format which can make audio files take up a very large percentage of a games' total size. This is the way it was done in XNA (too increase loading speed?), but wouldn't it be good to support a way to build compressed SoundEffects with the Content Pipeline Tool? The trade off for a smaller .xnb size would be a longer loading time but it would be up to each developer to decide if they want to do this tradeoff or not via some setting in the pipeline tool.

data.title: IOS SpriteFont data format problem on remote debug from visual studio
data.body:
I'm using Visual Studio 2015 CE to remotely build and debug an IOS app.  When I build and run the app from Xamarin on my mac, it works fine, but when I try from my PC, the build works, but there is a runtime exception when loading a spritefont:

    System.ArgumentException: elementCount is not the right size, elementCount * sizeof(T) is 131072, but data size is 262144.
    Parameter name: elementCount

Note that the data size is exactly twice expected size.   I suspect this also happens on any texture, but I have not tested that.

Details:
- the font.otf file is incorperated directly in the Content/Fonts folder and is referenced directly from the sprintfont file.
- The "Perform all 32bit floating point operations as 64 bit" option is unchecked
- The IOS project is pretty vanilla.  I haven't altered any compiling options that I can think of.

data.title: Windows StoreApps PreferredBackBufferWidth/Height bug
data.body:
PreferredBackBufferWidth/Height is wrong at startup when Client Width<Height.

W8.1 / WP8.1 Screenshots

![w81](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3018589/23714688/d98681f4-0432-11e7-8c41-6954d3f53170.png)
![wp81](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3018589/23714691/db0b07b6-0432-11e7-8489-cc999331297d.png)

The cause of this is https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/GraphicsDeviceManager.cs#L69-L78
which I assume is an attempt to [Automatic Rotation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff966425.aspx).
 
On W10 the values are still wrong during Game.Initialize(). After initialization W10 receives a SizeChange event that restores the values.
Even if W8.1/WP8.1 got a resize event the same code is present in MetroGameWindow.cs (UAPGameWindow.cs doesn't swap Width/Height),
https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Windows8/MetroGameWindow.cs#L157-L166

IMO it's best to remove this code entirely.

A proper implementation would be to change the Orientation when SupportedOrientations= Default and the game is fullscreen or runs in fullscreen environment (WP,Android,iOS).

Personally I think this behavior is confusing and goes a step too far. I found myself fighting against it in XNA in the past when trying to take advantage of the WP7 scaler.

data.title: Content Pipeline Extension project referencing error in Visual Studio 2017
data.body:
Please be seated before reading this.

I've found what I suspect is a bug/change in VS2017 with the $(MSBuildExtensionsPath) variable we use in the Content Pipeline project.

in 2015 and before, this correctly resolves to the MSBUILD folder on the dev machine.

in 2017 however, this is resolving to the Windows 8 MonoGame folder???  so as the Content Pipeline project DLL is nto packages with / per platform, this reference fails.

So need to investigate further to see what's causing this and whether a template change is required or whether we await a Visual Studio fix.

*On a side note
I noticed we don't actually have a proper Content Pipeline DLL, only the PCL one.
Having a full CP NuGet and using that in the project reference may be another easy way to resolve the issue.

data.title: Scale and Rotation properties in Matrix class return incorrect values
data.body: When calling the Scale and Rotation properties on the Matrix class, the values returned are often incorrect. I have been struggling to get some code to work for some time and discovered that by replacing these calls with a single call to Matrix.Decompose the correct values are returned. For example, calling Scale seems to always return 1,0,0 but when using Decompose the correct value 1,1,1 is returned.

data.title: [VR] Add a method to get native Ptr from a texture
data.body:
Hi,

I'm working on a VR implementation with Monogame for my game engine. The implementation is almost done, however I'm stuck because I need to have an access to the [texture's native pointer](https://github.com/demonixis/C3DE/blob/develop/C3DE/VR/OpenVRService.cs#L64).

There is a method called `GetSharedHandle()` that returns an IntPtr which is what I want. But Microsoft doesn't recommand to use it and it's not working in my case (it returns IntPtr.Zero).

Having access to the native pointer is mandatory for a VR implementation using a compositor (Oculus Home, SteamVR and soon OSVR). In fact you have to create two `RenderTarget2D` and pass their `IntPtr` to the VR SDK (the Submit method in my sources).

Without that, you can only have a non direct mode rendering and have to manage the screen size, placement, etc. (this is what Oculus did when the DK1 was released).

I'm working on the three implementations (Oculus, OpenVR and OSVR).

Thanks.

data.title: OpenAL error handling clean up
data.body:
This PR cleans up the error handling in the OpenAL device/context initialization by making it critical and throwing ```NoAudioHardwareException``` exceptions at any kind of error and adding the AL error code to its message.

It was previously not critical and was continuing execution with no AL device, which resulted in several difficult to debug situations (because the original AL error was lost, and raising non trivial error messages or unrelated exceptions). This now allows to get more info from remote crash reporters.

It also removes some initialization checks because initialization will now halt on all errors.

This is a first step to get better stack traces in an attempt to resolve #5381.

@dellis1972 @cra0zy @KonajuGames
